problem: If the two roots of the quadratic $7x^2+3x+k$ are $\frac{-3\pm i\sqrt{299}}{14}$, what is $k$?
model_solution:
Step 1: Recall that the quadratic formula is $x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$, where the roots of the quadratic equation $ax^{2}+bx+c=0$ are given by this formula.
Step 2: Set up the equation $\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}=\frac{-3\pm i\sqrt{299}}{14}$, where $a=7$, $b=3$, and $c=k$, and solve for $k$.
Step 3: Square both sides of the equation $\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}=\frac{-3\pm i\sqrt{299}}{14}$, and equate the real and imaginary parts.
Square both sides of the equation and equate the real parts: $\left(\frac{-3\pm i\sqrt{299}}{14}\right)^{2}=\frac{(-3)^{2}\pm2(-3)i\sqrt{299}+(-\sqrt{299})^{2}}{196}=\frac{9\mp6i\sqrt{299}+299}{196}$
Equate the real and imaginary parts of $\frac{9\mp6i\sqrt{299}+299}{196}$ and $\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$ to obtain two equations: $\frac{308}{196}=\frac{308}{196}$ and $\frac{-6\sqrt{299}}{196}=\frac{\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$
Solve the equation $\frac{-6\sqrt{299}}{196}=\frac{\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$ for $b^{2}-4ac$.
Solve the equation $(-6\sqrt{299})^{2}=\left(\frac{\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\right)^{2}$ for $b^{2}-4ac$.

$(-6\sqrt{299})^{2}=\left(\frac{\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\right)^{2}$ 
$\Rightarrow 1089a^{2}\left(\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}\right)^{2}=b^{2}-4ac$
$\Rightarrow 1089a^{2}\left(b^{2}-4ac\right)=b^{2}-4ac$
$\Rightarrow 1089a^{2}b^{2}-4\cdot 1089a^{3}c=b^{2}-4ac$
$\Rightarrow 1089a^{2}b^{2}-b^{2}=4\cdot 1089a^{3}c-4ac$
$\Rightarrow 1088a^{2}b^{2}=4ac\left(1089a^{2}-1\right)$
$\Rightarrow 272a^{2}b^{2}=ac\left(108
$\Rightarrow 272a^{2}b^{2}=ac\left(1089a^{2}-1\right)$
Equate the real and imaginary parts of $\frac{9\mp6i\sqrt{299}+299}{196}$ and $\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$ to obtain two equations: $\frac{308}{196}=\frac{308}{196}$ and $\frac{-6\sqrt{299}}{196}=\frac{\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}$
